description.narrative: The project objectives are to train Kuwaitis to become professional museum and laboratories employees in the preservation and display of selected artefacts from the Dar Al-Athar Al-Islamiyyah collection at the Kuwait National Museum.
independent political entity
policy, planning and administration

1. No. of Kuwaiti conservators of wood and stone artefacts (organic). 2. No. of Kuwaiti conservators of metal artefacts (non-organic). 3. No. of Kuwaiti conservators of ivory artefacts. 4. No. of Kuwaiti trainees to be installers for museum exhibitions selected. 5. No. of new Kuwaiti museum administrators. 6. No. of trained Kuwaiti museum teachers 7. No. of new Kuwaiti engineers for design and supervision 8. No. of trained Kuwaiti museum graphic designers.

comment.narrative: 1. There are no Kuwaiti conservators of wood and stone artefacts (organic). 2. There are no Kuwaiti conservators of metal artefacts (non-organic). 3. There are no Kuwaiti conservators of ivory artefacts. 4. There are no Kuwaiti Museum Installers for museum exhibitions. 5. No trained Kuwaiti museum administrators 6. No trained Kuwaiti museum teachers 7. Only 6 Kuwaiti Engineers for design and supervision 8. No trained Kuwaiti graphic designers.

Output 1: 1 - Assist Kuwaiti Authorities to undertake conservation work on the collection of the museum and undertake any other work in connection with the conservation of the collection - Provide training and advise to assistant conservators in the conservation work on the collection of the museum - liaise with other curatorial staff - Manage the conservation laboratories - Train and implement a program of environmental monitoring - Train and implement a Pest management programme - Train the strategies for the ‘house-keeping’ of the collection in the storage and on display - Outsource and manage external specialized expertize - Train and implement and carry out a programme of inhouse conservation (approx.. 33.000 objects) - Support the expert for the display of the artefacts in the museum - Undertake any other tasks pertaining to the consultancy deemed appropriate by DAI and UNDP. 2 - Assist Kuwaiti Authorities to undertake conservation work on the collection of the museum and undertake any other work in connection with the conservation of the collection. - Provide training and advise to assistant conservators in the conservation work on the collection of the museum - liaise with other curatorial staff - Undertake any other tasks pertaining to the consultancy deemed appropriate by DAI and UNDP. 3 - Assist Kuwaiti Authorities to undertake conservation work on the collection of the museum and undertake any other work in connection with the conservation of the collection. - Provide training and advise to assistant conservators in the conservation work on the collection of the museum - Liaise with other curatorial staff - Undertake any other tasks pertaining to the consultancy deemed appropriate by DAI and UNDP. 4. Assist Kuwaiti Authorities to undertake conservation work on the collection of the museum and undertake any other work in connection with the conservation of the collection. - Provide training and advise to assistant conservators in the conservation work

Output 1: Under guidance 3 Kuwaiti trainees have been involved with a diverse number of projects and in the normal processes involved in the care of the collection. All have been working on the continued programme of cleaning objects using the Q-switch Nd:YAG laser. Output 2: The expert mission terminated in the second quarter of 2014. DAI is now implementing the programs developed with the expert. As a result of the UNDP expert's work with the Dar al-Athar al-Islamiyyah’s education team, the DAI is currently offering four new programmes and five existing programmes. The new programmes extend DAI reach from age 6 to adult to age 18 months to adult and offer new opportunities for primary students in Kuwait to benefit from aspects of the museum experience in their own classrooms. The expanded programmes improve the interaction between the DAI, DAI museum educators and the participants, making the programmes more challenging and more rewarding. The DAI Education program coordinator was asked to briefly outline the major impacts that the UNDP-supported training session added to the program. Here are the results: 1. The DAI education team was already implementing some programmes quite well. However DAI didn’t know why they worked, making the chances of attaining the level of success in other programmes a matter of luck. By providing DAI with education theory and application tools, the Program now understand why some things work and others don’t and are able to build from there. 2. The DAI education team had ideas for additional programmes, but really had no idea how to implement them. For example, most museums in the West offer programmes for children starting at 18 months and we recognized that that was important. But, what do you do with a toddler in a museum and what can you expect when working with toddlers? The expert helped DAI construct the necessary programmes (including the one for toddlers) by having DAI team work through the skills, social skills and abilities

title.narrative: Implementation of the National Traffic Strategy

description.narrative: Implementation of the Comprehensive and Long Term National Traffic and Transport Sector Strategy for Kuwait.

title.narrative: LoU - UNDP Kuwait and BoM PSO
Traffic Annual Progress Report Jan_ Dec 2013
CDR Report first quarter - Traffic project

description.narrative: Improve planning and design process; cost of road accidents to the community; optimize movement of people and goods; enhance public transport service; strength law enforcement; contribute to climate change.
independent political entity

Output 1: - Centralized / integrated electronic information system developed. - Capacity of GDT enhanced. - Information – specific cadres selected and trained.
Output 2: - Modern blackspot and road safety system established. - Accident investigation procedures enhanced. - Safety conscious - road design system established. - Specialised cadres in blackspot and road safety selected and trained.
Output 3: - Appropriate implementation process of the approved NTTS established nationwide. - Progress achieved toward implementation of the required institutional reform and staff training. - Centres of Excellence and new units established within the GDT. - Link with the private sector and stakeholders established to tackle traffic problems. - M & E system established.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: - No centralized / integrated electronic information system available. - Inadequate capacity of the GDT to provide traffic-related services for the stakeholders. - Lack of information expertise.
Output 2: - Absence of modern blackspot and road safety system. - Unavailability of modern accident investigation procedures. - Lack of accident documentations. - Shortage of specialised skills in blackspot and road safety. - Unavailability of safety conscious- road design system.
Output 3: - Lack of implementation of the Government approved NTTS by relevant Ministries. - Slow progress toward implementation of the required institutional reform to enhance capacity and optimize the use of resources. - Lack of efficient sector-specific skills. - Unavailability of equipment, software, systems, devices and guidelines.

Output 1: - Fully operational system in place and linked with relevant GDT Directorates - Protocol to download electronic data and collect data from various sources established - User manual and guidelines developed and disseminated to relevant GDT staff - Project website established and access provided to decision makers, practitioners and stakeholders - Operation police in all Governorates provided with iPAD for data collection - Relevant GDT Directorates provided with equipment and socialized software, and institutional management enhanced - 100 police officers, engineers and technician trained on the use of the system.
Output 2: - Uniform blackspot and road safety system in use in the 6 Governorates - National blackspot guidelines developed and disseminated within the GDT and for relevant Ministries - Accident investigation guidelines developed and disseminated within the GDT and General Directorate of Investigation - Identification and treatment of 50 blackspots locations per annum - Reduction of road traffic fatalities to below 460 - Reduction of fatality rate per 100,000 populations to below 14 - 160 National cadres trained in use of the system.
Output 3: - Efficient system established with support of the Supreme Traffic Council and Deputy Ministers to ensure implementation of the NTTS by relevant Ministries - Capacity of the GDT enhanced, and new transport authority approved by the National Assembly in July 2014 and established by the Government in October 2014, and operational support provided during 2015 - Organisational structures developed for the new Centres of Excellence and equipment and devises provided on time - Guidelines in traffic operations, awareness and driving license developed and disseminated - 2 International workshops for training of the national cadres in areas which are not available nationally addressed by the Ministers and attended by over 450 people - 80 women trained in specialized areas - Joint programs with the stakeholders, c

Output 1: - Continuation of building the NTIS system. - Continuation of assessment of traffic congestion and plotting of GIS map data – ongoing task. - Coordination with General Directorate of Traffic and relevant departments for information system design, development and interfacing of relevant data - ongoing task. - Installation of GIS hardware and software in new Project Office with the networking datasets – ongoing task. - Scanning of GIS / AutoCAD maps received from Ministry of Electricity and Water (MEW) is in progress for identifying electricity poles location in Kuwait which will be used in the “Out of the Box” software system – ongoing task. - ArcGIS Personal Geodatabase for electricity poles location is under progress from the AutoCAD maps - ongoing task. - Settlements of TRL Team in Strategy Project office at GDT HQ. - Identification of required software, system and information for the successful bidder of the “Out of the Box” software. - Maps scanning and plotting of important landmarks by using A0 scanner – ongoing task. - Continuation of the Project Team in the development of Accidents, Traffic, Offences and other relevant information and system using the available resources. - Project Initiation Meeting with TRL team Conducted on 2nd Aug 2015 on the Project overview. - Accident Reporting Form (ARF) review discussion meeting with TRL team on 11 Aug 2015, TRL provided a live demo of the iMAAP system to MOI & UNDP and demonstrated various features of iMAAP. - Accident Reporting Form has been completed by TRL as per the planned activities and approved by GDT with slight modifications. - Various progress meetings have been conducted by Project Team and Project coordinators, GDT-MOI as mentioned below.
Output 2: - Continuation of assessment of traffic congestion and preparation of GIS maps – ongoing task. - Continuation of study of black spot data. - Coordination with General Directorate of Traffic and relevant departments for database design & development

description.narrative: Women Legal empowerment Project

title.narrative: Request from the beneficiary partner for project’s budget increase
WARACTI Project's CDR for 1st Quarter year 2014

description.narrative: Promoting Legal Empowerment of Women in the State of Kuwait-WRACATI
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - social services (incl youth development and women+ children)

1. Relevant legal information is compiled, reviewed and presented in user-friendly format. 2. Relevant legal information is produced on CDs, radio messages, booklets, posted on the project website and disseminated. 3. Number of persons accessing legal information and the project website users. 4. Number and quality of press releases on gender in national and regional media enhanced. 5. Major activities (project roll-out conference and events) of the project are covered by the media and receive public attention. 6.Social media effectively used to spread messages and flag issues

comment.narrative: 1. Systematic compilation of legal information on laws and court rulings is incomplete or is not available. 2. Existing legal information is not user-friendly and not easily accessible. 3. Media does not have sufficient knowledge and or qualifications to report on gender-related issues. 4. Awareness of women’s legal rights among the general public not well developed.
Project was closed by end 2014.
Project was closed operationally in 2015.

title.narrative: Support to Public Authority of Manpower

description.narrative: PAM is partnering with UNDP, IOM& ILO to improve the labor conditions. This prog aims to support PAM to develop internal capacity in reporting on its own performance, on labor movement & on compliance with int'l labor standards.

PAM plans to improve the labour conditions and management system by analysing the demographic imbalance, making sound decision based on enhanced reporting mechanisms and upgrading its services quality for all economic and social actors.
policy, planning and administration

Output 2.1: - Research programmes deliver data and knowledge that support evidence-based policy-making in PAM. - PAM has greater understanding of how non-market factors impact labour mobility in GoK and recommendations on how to address this. - # of adjustments to PAM procedures carried out to better align with labour market objectives, as per recommendations of report. Output 2.1: - GoK/PAM have new information available to further improve and/or expand the shelter - GoK/PAM have new skills and knowledge regarding shelter management - GoK/PAM exposed to best practices, lessons learned, and able to share information on shelter management - GoK/PAM informed of the operational and cost advantage of AVRR - Migrants are returned home voluntarily and provided with reintegration assistance. Output 3.1: No of Government, Employers and Workers representatives participated in a Standards training course in the ILO Training Centre in Turin. Output 3.2: No. of workshops held on the ratification and application of conventions 100, 111, 122, 129,187, and 189. Output 3.3: - International Labour Standards taken into account in court proceedings - No of trainers and judges from Kuwait trained in the ILO Training Centre in Turin - No of Information materials produced in Arabic Language. Output 3.4: - Number of capacity building workshops held on ILS implementation for parliamentarians. Output 4.1: 1- Number of Employees of Public Authority of Manpower leadership team trained. 2-Number of Enforcement Priorities established & Enforcement Plan developed. Output 4.2: - Assessment and recommendations completed Output 4.3: - Action Plan developed. Output 4.4: - Enforcement Plan implemented. Output 4.5: - National OSH Policy, Profile and Programme are produced. Output 4.6: - Number of training courses are conducted on basic OSH and risk assessment. Output 4.7: - No of OSH specialists receiving specialized training on the use of OSH equipment Output 4.8: - No of training courses for Wo

comment.narrative: Output 2.1: - No research capacity to support evidence-based policy development. - Limited knowledge of non-market drivers of labour mobility. - Labour Mobility Management Structures not fully aligned with GoK’s labour market and economic development goals. Output 2.2: - No available assessment of shelter - No. of workshops held on shelter management - No of study tours held on shelter management - No of technical roundtables on shelter management - No available information on feasibility of AVRR - No migrants assisted with AVRR. Output 3.1: Not enough training to Kuwait Government and social partners, on reporting. Output 3.2: - Insufficient capacity related to international labour standards. Output 3.3: - Not enough training on international Labour Standards. Output 3.4: - No capacity building workshops to parliamentarians held. Output 4.1: 1- No training of a leadership team. 2- No enforcement priorities and no existing plan. Output 4.2: - No existing Labour inspection assessment Output 4.3: - No action plan Output 4.4: - No action plan Output 4.5: - No existing national OSH profile. Output 4.6: - Not enough training of inspectors on OSH. Output 4.7: - No technical capacity of inspectors for monitoring environmental pollutants in the workplace Output 4.8: - weak capacity of employers’ and workers’ representatives on LI and OSH. Output 4.9: - No existing tools. Output 5.1: - No team assembled for the data gathering - No database for gathering and storing data - No data analyzed in graphical form - No data analyzed from month to month Output 5.2: - No database for gathering and storing data - No process for reporting formulated at PAM -No reporting team established Output 5.3: - No training conducted on PAM staff to create, and produce the reports - No training conducted for remaining PAM staff to understand and analyze reports.

Output 1: Programme management unit established and functional Output 2: - Appropriate staff, PAM focal point, and consultants in place, and steering committee established; - Three comprehensive research reports and three dissemination workshops contribute to evidence-based decisions in PAM; - PAM authorities officially recognize value of research and support ongoing research to inform policy development; - % of workshop participants acknowledging greater understanding of non-market drivers and able to implement knowledge in their day-to-day work; - PAM evaluates and implements at least five of the recommendations to better align labour mobility management structures with economic development objectives. -Shelter report issued - PAM staff trained on shelter management- 50 - Study tour to share best practices- 1 - Technical roundtable- 1 - Pre & post feasibility assessment on AVRR- 2 - Migrants provided with AVRR- 75 Output 3: - At least 8 Government, 8 Employers and 8 Workers representatives participated in a Standards training course in the ILO Training Centre in Turin. - At least one workshop held on the ratification and application of conventions 100, 111, 122, 129,187, and 189. - Three trainers of the Kuwait Institute for Judicial Studies, and 5 judges from Kuwait, 2 from each of other GCC countries trained in an interregional activity for judges and lawyers in the ILO Training Centre in Turin. - At least 1 capacity building workshops held on ILS implementation for parliamentarians. Output 4: - A leadership team of employees of Public Authority of Manpower trained. - Needed Enforcement Priorities established and enforcement Plan developed for 24 month period. - Assessment and recommendations completed. - Action Plan developed based on Assessment and in support of Enforcement Plan. - 75% of Enforcement Plan implemented. - OSH Profile implemented by PAM. - All PAM inspectors trained on basic OSH and risk assessment. - At least six OSH specialists including wom

Project has initiated by mid 2015 even it was signed by January 2015. It has partially delays in its activities but it is on track currently; the following results have been achieved in 2015: - UNDP Project Associate and Manager were hired in the last quarter of 2015. - PAM team has been identified and a PSO office has been established to work on development projects - Selection of project assistants, manager, and required technical consultants is finalized. - IOM launched a TOR and a Call for Proposal and has selected research consultants for two selected corridors to Kuwait - Participation of two government representatives in a standard training course in Turin in May 2015 and another two November 2015.

description.narrative: The ICDI/KNDP project seeks to provide a framework of technical support to GSSCPD and CSB and other public entities to create an enabling environment for implementation, monitoring and evaluation and ultimately delivery of KNDP results.

The ICDI/KNDP project seeks to provide a framework of technical support to GSSCPD and CSB and other public entities to create an enabling environment for implementation, monitoring and evaluation and ultimately delivery of KNDP results.
Percentage of implementation of the National Development Plan

comment.narrative: New National Development Plan (2015-2018 -- implementation beginning 1 Sept 2015)

Technical support to the restructuring and upgrading of the public administration at the GSSCPD producing an implementation plan for strategic reorganization. Upgrade GSSCPD monitoring and evaluation mechanisms for implementation of KNDP Establishmet of a consultancy roster for functional and technical advisory services that applies a an on-going assessment of productivity for service delivery Develop and enhance statistical foundation for new KNDP indicators Provision of demand-based recruitment of technical experts for public entities

Creation of a Human Resources Strategy 2015-2025 for GSSCPD, informed by the institutional skills audit with an HR database, executive plan, SOPs and a staff capacity development plan (skills) Creation of an effective M&E mechanism based on an assessment, gaps analysis that includes necessary database, systems or tools Delivery of the action plan with development of 12 generic profiles as a first stage for the establishment of a consultancy roster Technical support through Experts to the development of the CSB 1. indicators; 2.sampling and survey techniques;3.assess and monitor KOPSII;4.International/Foreign Trade;5.Labour Market Statistics for National indicators for economic development Technical Experts were provided to the following national entities to assist in developing sectorial plans linked to the NMRDP.
